title: At what height will the acceleration due to gravity be reduced to 36% of its value on the surface of the Earth? - Quora

response.answer_text: The acceleration of free fall due to gravity can be mathematically worked out as follows : mg = GMm/R^2, where mg is the weight of the object which is the same as the force on the object due to gravity. So solving for g gives : g = GM/R^2. This shows you that as R increases or the distance between the object and earth's center of gravity, the value of g will go down inversely to the second power of the distance ! Now if the acceleration due to gravity at a certain height above the earth were to be 36% of g or 0.36g, then the new R'(Radius plus height) can be mathematically worked out as follows :— With the use of the equation R = (GM/g)^1/2. So now let's get the ratio of R when a is g, and R' when a is 0.36g. This goes as follows : R/R' = {(GM/g)^1/2}/{(GM/0.36g)^1/2). Here, then (R/R')^2= (GM/g)/(GM/0.36g) = 0.36, where (GM/g) cancels out, which leads to (R/R')^2 = 0.36, which leads to R/R' = 0.6, So R = 0.6R', or flipping it R' = 5/3 R. Earth's average radius is 6,367 km, hence R' = 10,612 km, hence the height on top of the earth's surface will be R' - R which will give you the height of 4,245 km above the earth. Kaiser T, MD.

The acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the earth is g=GMR2,g=GMR2, where G,MG,M and RR are the gravitational constant, mass of the earth and radius of the earth respectively. Let the acceleration due to gravity be g′g′ at a height hh above the surface of the earth. ⇒g′=GM(R+h)2.⇒g′=GM(R+h)2. It is given that the acceleration due to gravity is reduced by 36%36% at height h.h. ⇒g′=g(1−36100)=g(64100).⇒g′=g(1−36100)=g(64100). ⇒g′g=R2(R+h)2=(64100).⇒g′g=R2(R+h)2=(64100). ⇒RR+h=64100−−−√=810=45.⇒RR+h=64100=810=45. ⇒5R=4(R+h)=4R+4h⇒h=R4.⇒5R=4(R+h)=4R+4h⇒h=R4. The required height is one fourth of the radius of the earth. The radius of the earth is approximately 63716371 km. ⇒⇒ The required height is 1592.751592.75 km.

Gravity decreases with the square of distance (including Earth's radius). Solving generally, with q=0.36q=0.36 to be inserted later: (RR+h)2=q(RR+h)2=q 1+hR=q−0.51+hR=q−0.5 h=R(q−0.5−1)h=R(q−0.5−1) Plugging in R=6400R=6400 km and q=0.36q=0.36, we get: h=6400×(1/0.6−1)=6400×0.6666667≈4267h=6400×(1/0.6−1)=6400×0.6666667≈4267 km. Note that physically, this only make sense if you have h>0h>0 i.e., q<1q<1. If we go beneath Earth's surface, we “gain” in decreasing the distance to the center, but we lose more by losing mass that is no longer attracting us. (late edit:) What about the case when q=1−αq=1−α, where αα is small? The first order Taylor expansion gives us: h≈Rα2h≈Rα2 So for example, if we want gravity to be reduced to 90% its value, we have α=0.1α=0.1 so h≈0.05Rh≈0.05R. This factor 22 (gaining a factor of 2 in terms of drop in gravity compared to the gain in altitude) is to be expected, since the original function was quadratic - its derivative was (normalized w.r.t. everything) equal to 2.

Gravitational acceleration at height h from the surface of the earth is given by g(h) = GM/(R+h)^2 = GM/[R^2(1+ h/R)^2. Here, G is universal gravitational constant. M and R are mass and mean radius of the earth respectively. But, GM/R^2=g(e). Therefore , g(h)=g(e)/[1+(h/R)]^2 OR g(h)/g(e)=1/[1+(h/R)]^2. But, g(h)/g(e)= 0.36 is given. This is if g reduces to 36% of the value on the surface of the earth. Therefore , 0.36=1/[1+(h/R)]^2…………..(1) Taking square root on both sides, 0.6=1/[1+(h/R)] OR 0.6[1+(h/R)]=1. Putting R= 6400 km, we have, 1+(h/6400)]=1.667 OR h/6400=0.667 OR h=6400x0.667=4269 km This is the answer if value of g becomes 36% of g on the surface of the earth. Now, if g reduces BY 36%, then, g(h)/g(e)=0.64. In this case equation (1) will become 0.64=1/[1+(h/R)]^2. Taking square root on both sides, 0.8=1/[1+(h/R)] OR 0.8[1+h/R]=1 OR 1+(h/R)=1.25 OR h/R=0.25 OR h=0.25R. But, R= 6400km. Then, h=1600 km.

r is the radius of earth . You want to know what height above earth is 0.36g, call this height h. Using newtons inverse square law F=GMm/r^2, we can derive h = 2r/3 where h is the height above earth surface at which gravity is 36% that of gravity on the surface. (I assume you just want the answer and not a full derivation) r (radius of earth) is 6371km, so using h = 2r/3 we get an altitude of 4,247km. So that is your answer. Gravity at that altitude is 36% of that on the surface. Just for perspective, the space station orbits at 408km, the gravity due to earth is 88.4% and the moon is 384,400 km away and earth's gravity there is about 0.03% of that on the earth's surface. Which isn't a lot, but when combined with the moons gravity is enough to keep it in orbit around the earth. Hope that helps
